comment.body: This (generated) code seems to contradict the documentation: "**Optimizations**: Portable C with AES, AVX2, POPCNT, SSE2 and SSSE3 instructions (if available at run-time)". Question: Did you build-and-run this branch locally once with OQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS=ON and once with OFF and see the expected performance differences?

pull_request.title: Sync upstream with copy_from_upstram / pqcrystals pull
pull_request.body:
This PR is to show the changes after copy_from_upstream with #880.

It will also be an alternative to #890.

With this configuration, it is pulling the latest Kyber round 3 and Dilithium round 3 from pqcrystals-upstream.

The updates can be reproduced like this:

```
$ ./copy_from_upstream copy
```

To verify that the synced version matches with upstream versions:

```
$ ./copy_from_upstream.py verify
-----
Total schemes: 151 - 151 match with upstream, 0 differ
-----
```

Note that this PR might have to be rebased after #880 is merged.

* [x] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)

Changes to Dilithium Round 3 KAT. Adds Dilithium Round 3 algorithms (2, 3, 5, 2-AES, 3-AES, 5-AES)

* [x] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding or removing?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,97 +1,142 @@
 # SPDX-License-Identifier: MIT
 
 # This file was generated by
-# scripts/copy_from_pqclean/copy_from_pqclean.py
+# scripts/copy_from_upstream/copy_from_upstream.py
 
 set(_KYBER_OBJS "")
 
+if(OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_512 OR OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_1024 OR OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_512_90s OR OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_768_90s OR OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_1024_90s)
+    add_library(kyber_common_ref OBJECT pqcrystals-kyber_common_ref/aes256ctr.c pqcrystals-kyber_common_ref/fips202.c)
+    target_include_directories(kyber_common_ref PRIVATE ${CMAKE_CURRENT_LIST_DIR}/pqcrystals-kyber_common_ref)
+    set(_KYBER_OBJS ${_KYBER_OBJS} $<TARGET_OBJECTS:kyber_common_ref>)
+endif()
+
+if(OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_512_avx2 OR OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_768_avx2 OR OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_1024_avx2 OR OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_512_90s_avx2 OR OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_768_90s_avx2 OR OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_1024_90s_avx2)
+    add_library(kyber_common_avx2 OBJECT pqcrystals-kyber_common_avx2/fips202.c pqcrystals-kyber_common_avx2/fips202x4.c)
+    target_include_directories(kyber_common_avx2 PRIVATE ${CMAKE_CURRENT_LIST_DIR}/pqcrystals-kyber_common_avx2)
+    target_compile_options(kyber_common_avx2 PRIVATE -mavx2)
+    set(_KYBER_OBJS ${_KYBER_OBJS} $<TARGET_OBJECTS:kyber_common_avx2>)
+endif()
+
+if(OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_512_avx2 OR OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_768_avx2 OR OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_1024_avx2)
+    add_library(kyber_common_keccak4x_avx2 OBJECT pqcrystals-kyber_common_keccak4x_avx2/keccak4x/KeccakP-1600-times4-SIMD256.c)
+    target_include_directories(kyber_common_keccak4x_avx2 PRIVATE ${CMAKE_CURRENT_LIST_DIR}/pqcrystals-kyber_common_keccak4x_avx2)
+    target_compile_options(kyber_common_keccak4x_avx2 PRIVATE -mavx2)
+    set(_KYBER_OBJS ${_KYBER_OBJS} $<TARGET_OBJECTS:kyber_common_keccak4x_avx2>)
+endif()
+
+if(OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_512_90s_avx2 OR OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_768_90s_avx2 OR OQS_ENABLE_KEM_kyber_1024_90s_avx2)
+    add_library(kyber_common_aes OBJECT pqcrystals-kyber_common_aes/aes256ctr.c)
+    target_include_directories(kyber_common_aes PRIVATE ${CMAKE_CURRENT_LIST_DIR}/pqcrystals-kyber_common_aes)
+    target_compile_options(kyber_common_aes PRIVATE -maes -msse2 -mssse3)
comment.body: Ahh -- this explains my confusion probably: Does SSSE3 and SSE2 only apply to Kyber90s but not Kyber (-noAES)? If so, let's go ahead and merge.

comment.body: Yes,  SSSE3 and SSE2 is part of the AES-dependency, so only relevant for Kyber90s.
